Comment: Because they serve fundamentally different purposes. A U.S. state is a sovereign political entity with its own set of laws and its own government. A congressional district is a subdivision of a state that exists solely to provide representation in Congress.  If you get re-drawn into a new congressional district, your life does not change. You still get to vote for exactly one member of Congress, and you're still subject to the same state and federal laws.   If you were to be re-drawn into a new state, then suddenly you're living under different laws, regulations, tax systems, etc. Imagine if you owned a cannabis farm in a legal state, and then you get re-drawn into a state where cannabis is illegal. Or what if you get re-drawn from Washington (a state with no income tax) to Oregon. All of a sudden, you have to pay income tax to a state that you didn't choose to live in and a government that you had no say in electing.  You might as well not even call them "states" at that point. A state derives its power from the consent of the governed. If people are getting arbitrarily forced into different states, then the consent doesn't exist anymore.

Comment: Because again this isn't a unitary nation. There's nothing imagined about it, states are independent pre-existing sovereign entities who surrendered portions of their sovereignty to create the federal government. They still retain most of their sovereignty and powers not expressly given to the federal government in the Constitution are reserved for the states or the people through the 10th amendment.  Districts are simple lines on paper and do not have any power as they are not political entities like counties, municipalities, and even school districts all of which's power is derived from the state's sovereignty and is granted to them through its state constitution.  So again as districts are not a political entity but simply a geographic division, like postal zip codes or telephone area codes, used to help with the logistics of voting, there is no uniting or pooling resources.
